The acidic property of WO3/Al2O3 catalysts loaded with WO3 (5–37 wt%) and their activity for gas-phase glycerol dehydration were investigated. Temperature-programmed desorption of NH3 revealed the formation of weak acid sites (the enthalpy of NH3 desorption; ΔH NH3 <110 kJ mol–1) on WO3/Al2O3. Infrared spectra of adsorbed pyridine indicated that a part of Lewis acid sites of WO3/Al2O3 was converted to Brønsted acid sites by water vapor treatment. The ΔH ‡–ΔS ‡ relationship for glycerol dehydration over WO3/Al2O3 and H-ZSM-5 indicated a weaker interaction of WO3/Al2O3 catalyst with the reaction intermediate than that of H-ZSM-5. The coke species deposited over WO3/Al2O3 and H-ZSM-5 were confirmed to consist of C3–C4 compounds, acrolein, benzene, toluene, xylene, glycerol, indenes, naphthalenes, and anthracenes (or phenanthrenes); fewer polyaromatic compounds were formed over WO3/Al2O3. For WO3/Al2O3, the weak acid strength of the Brønsted acid sites resulted in high durability for glycerol dehydration. Currently, biofuels are the primary alternative energy source to replace fossil fuels; therefore, biofuel production is increasing annually [2]. Approximately 10 wt% of glycerol is produced as a byproduct of biodiesel production through transesterification, and numerous studies have focused on utilizing glycerol for a sustainable society [3]. Glycerol is a platform for C3 chemicals and derivatives, such as carboxylic acids, acrolein, olefins, diols, and aldehydes, which are produced via oxidation, dehydration, and hydrogenolysis. Acrolein is particularly critical as a raw material for high-value chemical products, such as methionine (an essential amino acid) and acrylic acid (a functional material resource). Several studies have reported the dehydration of glycerol to acrolein using solid acid catalysts [4–27]. H-ZSM-5 has been used for the gas-phase dehydration of glycerol due to its high acrolein selectivity [24]. Supported tungsten oxide, molybdenum oxide, and niobium oxide catalysts also show high activity for glycerol dehydration [17,22,26]. Brønsted acid sites have been proposed to facilitate acrolein formation. Most studies investigating the gas phase dehydration of glycerol use aqueous glycerol solutions in the concentration range of 10–30 wt%. Therefore, glycerol and water are competitively adsorbed on the solid acid catalyst during the reaction. In fact, the relationship between water, the nature of acid sites on solid acid catalysts, and their activity has been reported. Kim et al. investigated the effect of the SiO2/Al2O3 ratio on H-ZSM-5 and water adsorption on the Lewis acid sites, which prevents the adsorption of glycerol during the gas phase dehydration of glycerol [25]. Foo et al. reported the adsorption of water molecules on Lewis acid sites over niobium oxides to form OH groups, resulting in the conversion of the Lewis acid sites to Brønsted acid sites [17]. Recently, Aihara reported that WO3/Al2O3 catalysts exhibit high acrolein selectivity and coking resistance during glycerol dehydration using an aqueous solution (10 mol%). On the other hand, the activities of WO3/ZrO2 and WO3/TiO2 catalysts decreased rapidly, although the structure of tungsten oxide was almost similar regardless of the support [27]. The effect of water on the acidic properties is essential for the development of glycerol dehydration catalysts with high efficiency, however, it is still under discussion. In this study, the acidic property of WO3/Al2O3 catalysts was investigated using the temperature-programmed desorption of NH3 (NH3-TPD), infrared (IR) spectra of adsorbed pyridine, a kinetic analysis of glycerol dehydration, and thermogravimetric analyses (TGAs) of the spent catalysts. In addition, pyrolysis-gas chromatography/mass spectrometry (Py-GC/MS), a technique based on thermal analysis, was used to characterize the carbon species deposited on the spent catalysts. We proposed that the weak acid strength of the Brønsted acid sites on WO3/Al2O3 catalysts resulted in high durability for glycerol dehydration. 2 Experimental 2.1. Catalyst preparation In this study, γ-Al2O3 (JRC-ALO-8) and H-ZSM-5 (JRC-Z5–90H) were supplied by the Catalysis Society of Japan (Tokyo, Japan), and (NH4)10W12O41 · 5H2O was purchased from Fujifilm Wako Pure Chemical, Osaka, Japan. Here, γ-Al2O3 and H-ZSM-5 were calcined at 773 K for 3 h in air, prior to catalyst preparation. Supported WO3 catalysts were prepared by impregnating the supports with an aqueous solution of (NH4)10W12O41, followed by drying at 353 K for 6 h and calcining at 1123 K for 3 h in air [28–29]. The surface coverage of Al2O3 with a WO3 monolayer was estimated using the cross-sectional area of a WO6 octahedral unit (0.22 nm2) [30]. The general properties and X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of the catalysts are shown in Table S1 and Fig. S1, respectively. 2.2. Gas phase dehydration of glycerol The gas-phase dehydration of glycerol was conducted in a fixed-bed glass reactor with an inner diameter of 4 mm, at ambient pressure in a He atmosphere. Prior to the reaction, the catalyst was placed in the middle of the reaction tube (the volume of catalyst: 2.1 × 10−8 m3) and treated with He at 588 K for 1 h. An aqueous solution of glycerol (10 mol%) was fed through the top of the reactor with a He flow of 20 mL min–1. The feed rate of glycerol was 5.1 mmol h–1. The composition of the gaseous mixture was 1/9/10 (substrate/H2O/carrier gas molar ratio). The total gas flow rate was 2.5 × 10−3 m3 h−1 (Gaseous hourly space velocity (GHSV): 1.2 × 105 h−1), and the contact time (total gas catalyst volume/flow rate) was estimated to be 30 ms. The liquid products were collected every hour in ice (273 K) and dry ice-methanol traps (195 K) and analyzed using a gas chromatograph/time-of-flight mass spectrometer (GC-TOFMS, JMS-T200GC, JEOL, Tokyo, Japan) with a Stabilwax (Restek, Bellefonte, PA, USA) capillary column (30 m). The initial formation rates of acrolein and acetol were determined based on the amount of product produced up to 1 hour after the start of the reaction and the weight of the catalyst to minimize the effect of carbon deposition on the formation rate of the product. The carbon balances of the evaluated catalysts in their steady states were >90%. 2.3. Characterizations XRD patterns of the catalysts were recorded using a SmartLab (Rigaku, Tokyo, Japan) operated at 40 kV and 40 mA with Cu Kα radiation; the samples were scanned in a 2θ range of 10–70° with a step size of 0.01°. The surface area and pore volume were determined from N2 isotherms using a BELSORP-mini II instrument (Microtrac Bell, Osaka, Japan) at 77 K. The catalyst was evacuated at 573 K for 3 h prior to analysis, and its surface area was estimated using the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method. NH3-TPD was performed to characterize the acidic properties of solid acid catalysts according to the method reported by Niwa and Katada [31]. A quartz cell and He carrier gas were used. The sample (50 mg) was loaded into the quartz cell and pretreated under a He flow (100 mL min–1) at 773 K for 1 h; for NH3 adsorption, NH3 (2.5 vol.%) /He was used at a flow rate of 100 mL min–1 for 30 min at 373 K, followed by He-purging for 30 min. After NH3 adsorption, water-vapor treatment was conducted using H2O (1.5 kPa) /He at 100 mL min–1 for 30 min, followed by He-purging for 30 min. The temperature was linearly increased from 303 to 873 K (10 K min–1), and the outlet flow was analyzed using a quadrupole mass analyzer (JMS-Q1050, JEOL). A curve fitting of the NH3-TPD profile can be used to evaluate the acid strength, the number of acid sites, and acid-site distribution on the solid acid catalysts [32]. Fourier transform IR (FT-IR) spectra were recorded using a VIR-200 instrument (JASCO, Tokyo, Japan) equipped with a mercury cadmium telluride (MCT/M) detector (64 scans were recorded for each spectrum at a resolution of 4 cm–1). Each sample was pressed onto a self-supporting wafer with a diameter of 20 mm. The sample was pretreated under O2 (25 kPa) at 773 K for 1.5 h to remove carbon contaminants, followed by evacuation at 773 K for 1 h. The sample was then exposed to pyridine (0.5 kPa) at 303 K for 30 min and evacuated at 423 K for 30 min, and subsequently exposed to water vapor (1.5 kPa) for 1 h and evacuated for 30 min at various temperatures. A TG/DTA-7300 instrument (Hitachi, Tokyo, Japan) was used for TGA; each sample was loaded onto a Pt pan and heated from 303 to 1173 K at 10 K min–1 in air (300 mL min–1). An EGA/PY-3030D instrument (Frontier Laboratories, Koriyama, Japan), installed on a GC-TOFMS with a 60 m J&W DB-1 capillary column (Agilent Technologies, Santa Clara, CA, USA), was used for Py-GC/MS; the pyrolyzer and interface temperatures were set to 873 and 573 K, respectively, and the spent catalysts were placed in a deactivated stainless-steel cup and introduced into the pyrolyzer. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Evaluation of the acidic property of WO3/Al2O3 by NH3-TPD The acidic properties of WO3/Al2O3 with different WO3 loadings were estimated from the NH3-TPD. Fig. 1 shows the NH3-TPD profiles of WO3/Al2O3 with different WO3 loadings. According to the method reported by Niwa and Katada [33,34], water vapor treatment was carried out after NH3 adsorption, to remove the physically adsorbed NH3 molecules. The NH3-TPD profiles of WO3/Al2O3 contained broad desorption peaks, and the peak maxima shifted to lower temperatures with increasing the WO3 loading. The maximum amount of acid sites was observed on the 18wt% WO3/Al2O3 catalyst, where a WO3 monolayer covered almost the entire Al2O3 surface (Table S1). The results of curve fitting of the NH3-TPD profiles of WO3/Al2O3 and H-ZSM-5 are shown in Fig. 2 and Figs. S2–S10. Niwa et al. evaluated the acid strengths of various zeolites using NH3-TPD and determined the enthalpies of NH3 desorption (ΔH NH3) [31]. The temperature of the desorption peak of the TPD profile represents the dominant acid strength [32]. To obtain the dominant acid strength for each catalyst, the number of peaks and the standard deviation were determined to minimize the difference between the measured and simulated values (the residual dispersion was less than 1 × 10−6). The ΔH NH3 values were calculated using a one-point method [32], as shown in Fig. S10. The ΔH NH3 value of H-ZSM-5 was 132 kJ mol–1, based on the following fitting parameters: σ = 4 kJ mol–1 (standard deviation) and the entropy change (ΔS = 146 J mol–1); this ΔH NH3 value is consistent with previous results [31]. The NH3-TPD profile of 18 wt% WO3/Al2O3 was deconvoluted into six peaks using σ = 4 kJ mol–1; the peaks, labeled a, b, c, d, e, and f, showed ΔH NH3values of 108, 115, 125, 135, 142, and 158 kJ mol–1, respectively (Fig. 2). In a previous study, the acid strength of zeolites was analyzed using the relationship between their ΔH NH3 values and crystal structures [33]. The acid strength due to the zeolite framework was classified into the following categories: MOR (>130 kJ mol–1) > MFI (120–130 kJ mol–1) > BEA (110–130 kJ mol–1) > FAU (<110 kJ mol–1). Based on the results of curve fitting, we categorized the acid strength of acid sites on WO3/Al2O3 as follows: strong (>130 kJ mol–1), mild (110–130 kJ mol–1), and weak (<110 kJ mol–1). Fig. 3 shows the total number of acid sites (the sum of weak, mild, and strong acid sites) over WO3/Al2O3 as a function of the WO3 loading. The total amount of acid sites over WO3/Al2O3 increased with the WO3 loading up to 18 wt% (3.6 W nm−2), and the change in the fraction of weak acid sites (<110 kJ mol–1) was consistent with the change in the total amount of acid sites. On the other hand, the fractions of acid sites with mild (110–130 kJ mol–1) and strong (>130 kJ mol–1) acid sites were almost constant regardless of the WO3 loading. 3.2 Evaluation of the acidity of WO3/Al2O3 by IR spectra of adsorbed pyridine Fig. 4 shows the IR spectra of pyridine adsorbed on 18 wt% WO3/Al2O3 before and after water vapor (1.5 kPa) treatment together with their difference spectra. The bands at 1450 and 1540 cm–1 correspond to pyridine adsorbed on Lewis acid sites and Brønsted acid sites, respectively [35]. Treatment with water vapor decreased the intensity of the band at 1450 cm–1 and increased the intensity of the band at 1550 cm–1. This result indicates that the interaction between solid acid catalysts and water vapor increased the number of Brønsted acid sites and decreased the number of Lewis acid sites [17,36–38]. The band at 1635 cm−1 was attributed to the H-O-H bending of water molecules adsorbed on Lewis acid sites, suggesting the non-dissociative adsorption of water molecules on the Lewis acid sites of WO3/Al2O3. The change in the IR spectra of pyridine adsorbed on 18 wt% WO3/Al2O3 and H-ZSM-5 by water vapor treatment at different temperatures together with their difference spectra are shown in Figs. S11 and S12. Fig. 5 shows the change in the amount of pyridine adsorbed on the Brønsted acid sites (+ΔB) and that of the Lewis acid sites (–ΔL) on 18 wt% WO3/Al2O3 and H-ZSM-5 by water vapor treatment in the temperature range of 373–423 K. For both 18 wt% WO3/Al2O3 and H-ZSM-5, the values of +ΔB and –ΔL were almost equal and maintained in this temperature range. Omata and Nambu reported that the activity of niobium oxide for cumene cracking catalyzed by Brønsted acid sites was drastically increased by introducing the H2O vapor into the carrier gas [36]. The IR spectra of adsorbed pyridine on niobium oxide showed a reversible interconversion of Lewis acid sites and Brønsted acid sites by the adsorption and desorption of water on the pyridine-adsorbed niobium oxide. Based on the effect of water on the activity for cumene cracking and IR spectra of adsorbed pyridine, they proposed that the water molecule functions as Brønsted acid sites capable of releasing proton since the OH bond in the water molecule is weakened by non-dissociative adsorption on the Lewis acid site of niobium oxide. The Lewis acid sites are not permanently converted to the Brønsted acid sites with water molecules, and water can behave as a Brönsted acid site during repeated adsorption and desorption on Lewis acid sites on niobium oxide. As with niobium oxide, for WO3/Al2O3, it is likely that water molecules function as Brønsted acid sites by non-dissociative adsorption on the Lewis acid sites. 3.3 Activity and kinetic study of glycerol over the WO3/Al2O3 catalysts In general, the formation of acrolein proceeded preferentially on Brønsted acid sites, and acetol was formed on Lewis acid sites during glycerol dehydration [4,24,39-40]. It has been proposed that the secondary OH group of glycerol interacts with the Brønsted acid sites and the sequential elimination of the first water molecule proceeds. An enol intermediate is formed at the Brønsted acid site, followed by a secondary dehydration step, leading to the formation of acrolein. On the other hand, the terminal OH group of glycerol is more likely to interact with Lewis acid sites due to steric constraints. The concerted transfer of the terminal OH group of glycerol and the migration of H + from the internal carbon yields acetol. Figs. 6 and S13 show the conversion of glycerol, the yield of acrolein, selectivity for acrolein, and selectivity for acetol in the gas phase dehydration of H-ZSM-5 and WO3/Al2O3 with various WO3 loadings, respectively. Acrolein was formed as the main product together with acetol as a by-product. The highest conversion of glycerol was observed over 18 wt% WO3/Al2O3, and the conversion gradually and slightly decreased during the reaction. Although H-ZSM-5 showed high activity in the initial stage of the reaction, the activity was rapidly deactivated. Fig. 7 shows the relationship between the product formation rate and weak acidity of WO3/Al2O3 catalysts with different WO3 loading. A linear correlation between the initial acrolein formation rate and the amount of weak acid sites (with ΔH NH3 <110 kJ mol–1) of WO3/Al2O3 was clearly observed. This result suggests that weak Brønsted acid sites (with ΔH NH3 <110 kJ mol–1) functioned as active sites for glycerol dehydration; thus, WO3/Al2O3 showed higher activity and durability than H-ZSM-5. We previously reported the dehydration of polyols over WO3/Al2O3, WO3/ZrO2, and WO3/TiO2 catalysts with WO3 surface densities of 3–4 W nm−2. WO3/Al2O3 showed a higher acrolein yield and durability than WO3/ZrO2 and WO3/TiO2 catalysts [27]. This surface density (3–4 W nm−2) was sufficient for a WO3 monolayer to fully cover the support surface with WO3 monolayer (about 100% coverage with WO3 monolayer) [27,28]. Kitano et al. reported that a 2D WO3 monolayer is formed on WO3/Al2O3 around 100% coverage with WO3 monolayer, and Brønsted acid sites are generated at the WO3-domain boundaries [28]. Considering the reaction results, for WO3/Al2O3, it can be assumed that acrolein formation was promoted on Brønsted acid sites generated at the WO3-domain boundaries. Moreover, it seems that Brønsted acid sites derived from water molecules by non-dissociative adsorption on the Lewis acid site also acted as active sites for acrolein formation. The correlation between the formation rates (5 h of reaction) and the amount of weak acid sites is compared with that for the initial formation rate (Fig. S14). Even after 5 h of the reaction, acrolein formation rates correlated with the weak acidity of WO3/Al2O3. Fig. S15 shows the Eyring plots of glycerol dehydration over 18wt% WO3/Al2O3 and H-ZSM-5. The activation enthalpy, ΔH ‡, and activation entropy, ΔS ‡, of the WO3/Al2O3 catalysts with different WO3 loadings were obtained from the slope and intercept of the Eyring equation. For numerous adsorptions and reactions, compensation relationships between the changes in enthalpy (ΔH) and entropy (ΔS) can be established for, yielding linear relationships [41–49]. Here, the ΔH ‡–ΔS ‡ compensation effect indicates complexation in the rate-determining step. Nakamura et al. have reported linear relationships between ΔS and ΔH in the cracking of cumene and disproportionation of toluene over various solid acid catalysts and proposed transition state structures for these reactions [50]. The ΔH ‡–ΔS ‡ compensation plot of the gas-phase dehydration of glycerol over WO3/Al2O3 with various WO3 loadings is shown in Fig. 8 . A linear relationship was clearly observed. For 18 wt% WO3/Al2O3, the ΔS ‡ value was the highest. H-ZSM-5 showed the lowest ΔS ‡, due to a stronger interaction with the intermediate than that of WO3/Al2O3, resulting in low activation entropy. These results suggest that the Brønsted acid sites on WO3/Al2O3 were loosely associated with the glycerol dehydration intermediates. 3.4 Characterization of the spent catalysts by TGA and Py-GC/MS Fig. 9 shows the TGA thermograms of 18 wt% WO3/Al2O3 (a) and H-ZSM-5 (b) after glycerol dehydration for 5 h at 578 K. The thermograms of 18 wt% WO3/Al2O3 and H-ZSM-5 showed broad differential thermogravimetry (DTG) peaks in the temperature range of 400–900 K, indicating different types of carbon species. The peak temperatures of 18 wt% WO3/Al2O3 and H-ZSM-5 were approximately 780 and 880 K, respectively. The DTG profile of H-ZSM-5 after glycerol dehydration shows peaks representing mass losses at 523, 623–673, and 800–850 K, which are attributed to glycerol trapped in its long channels, oligomerized species, and thermally unstable coke formed on the catalyst surface, respectively [51]. Ali et al. have reported that the weight loss peak of H-ZSM-5 at about 800–850 K is shifted to a higher temperature during glycerol dehydration due to the conversion of thermally unstable carbonaceous residues to more stable species via hydrogen transfer over nanocrystalline H-ZSM-5 [18]. This conversion is caused by the microporous channel structure of H-ZSM-5 and the rapid deactivation of glycerol dehydration, due to micropore obstruction. The BET surface area of H-ZSM-5 decreases drastically during the dehydration of glycerol, whereas WO3/Al2O3 maintains BET surface area [27]. Based on TGA thermograms, the acid sites of 18 wt% WO3/Al2O3 are accessible and can alleviate the mass transfer limitation of glycerol dehydration to a greater extent than zeolites. Py-GC/MS was used to identify the nature of the coke species deposited on the acid catalysts. Fig. 10 shows the pyrograms of 18 wt% WO3/Al2O3 (a) and H-ZSM-5 (b) obtained by Py-GC/MS after glycerol dehydration at 578 K for 5 h. In both pyrograms, peaks corresponding to C3–C4 species, acrolein, benzene, toluene, xylene, glycerol, indenes, naphthalenes, and anthracenes (or phenanthrenes) were observed. In the pyrogram of 18 wt% WO3/Al2O3, the peaks representing C3–C4 species and acrolein were very intense, while those representing the aromatics and polycyclic aromatics were weaker. The predominant pyrolysates of H-ZSM-5 were aromatic compounds, and the intensities of the peaks representing C3–C4 species and acrolein were lower in the pyrogram of H-ZSM-5 than that of WO3/Al2O3; thus, the amount of polycyclic aromatics formed on 18 wt% WO3/Al2O3 was smaller than that on H-ZSM-5. It has been proposed that the coke formation on metal oxides is mainly due to cracking catalyzed by acid sites, while hydrogen transfer and cyclization reactions of intermediates formed on the acid sites lead to the formation of aromatic compounds [52–55]. Therefore, the Brønsted acidity of WO3/Al2O3 was weaker than that of H-ZSM-5; the weak Brønsted acid sites generated over WO3/Al2O3 prevented coke formation via polycyclic reactions, while the active sites of the catalyst remained accessible. 4 Conclusion The acidic property of WO3/Al2O3 catalysts was investigated by the NH3-TPD and IR spectra of adsorbed pyridine. NH3-TPD revealed that the total amount of acid sites on WO3/Al2O3 increased with the WO3 loading up to 18 wt%, and the change in the fraction of weak acid sites (<110 kJ mol–1) was consistent with the change in the total amount of acid sites. IR of adsorbed pyridine indicated that a part of the Lewis acid sites of WO3/Al2O3 was converted to Brønsted acid sites by water vapor treatment. It is likely that water molecules function as Brønsted acid sites by non-dissociative adsorption on the Lewis acid site. The rate of acrolein formation during glycerol dehydration correlated well with the weak Brønsted acidity. The ΔH ‡–ΔS ‡ relationship for glycerol dehydration over WO3/Al2O3 and H-ZSM-5 indicating a weaker interaction of the WO3/Al2O3 catalyst with the intermediate than that of H-ZSM-5. Using pyrolysis-gas chromatography/mass spectrometry (Py-GC/MS), we found that the coke species deposited over WO3/Al2O3 and H-ZSM-5 consisted of C3–C4 compounds, acrolein, benzene, toluene, xylene, glycerol, indenes, naphthalenes, and anthracenes (or phenanthrenes). The ratio of polycyclic compounds formed on WO3/Al2O3 was much lower than that on H-ZSM-5. We proposed that the weak acid strength of the Brønsted acid sites resulted in high durability for glycerol dehydration on WO3/Al2O3. Credit author statement T. coredata.dc:description: The acidic property of WO3/Al2O3 catalysts loaded with WO3 (5–37 wt%) and their activity for gas-phase glycerol dehydration were investigated. Temperature-programmed desorption of NH3 revealed the formation of weak acid sites (the enthalpy of NH3 desorption; ΔH NH3 <110 kJ mol–1) on WO3/Al2O3. Infrared spectra of adsorbed pyridine indicated that a part of Lewis acid sites of WO3/Al2O3 was converted to Brønsted acid sites by water vapor treatment. The ΔH ‡–ΔS ‡ relationship for glycerol dehydration over WO3/Al2O3 and H-ZSM-5 indicated a weaker interaction of WO3/Al2O3 catalyst with the reaction intermediate than that of H-ZSM-5. The coke species deposited over WO3/Al2O3 and H-ZSM-5 were confirmed to consist of C3–C4 compounds, acrolein, benzene, toluene, xylene, glycerol, indenes, naphthalenes, and anthracenes (or phenanthrenes); fewer polyaromatic compounds were formed over WO3/Al2O3. For WO3/Al2O3, the weak acid strength of the Brønsted acid sites resulted in high durability for glycerol dehydration.
coredata.dc:title: Acidic property and gas-phase glycerol-dehydration activity of WO3/Al2O3 catalysts
